metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Respondent Firm

facts.text: The respondent assessee had been registered as a firm under s. 26A of the Income-tax Act for the year 1946-47.

For assessment years 1947-48, 1948-49 and 1949-50, the Income-tax Officer made assessments on the respondent on June 7, 1949 (for 1947-48), June 7, 1949 (for 1948-49), and September 23, 1949 (for 1949-50) under s. 23(3) of the Act.
The Income-tax Officer estimated profits under proviso to s. 13 and computed total income at Rs. 95,053 (1947-48), Rs. 93,430 (1948-49), Rs. 83,752 (1949-50).
The respondent applied for and obtained renewal of registration.
Income-tax Officer passed order under s. 23(6) allocating shares.

Respondent appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner (AAC). On November 4, 1950, AAC reduced estimated profit by Rs. 28,250 for 1947-48 and Rs. 19,000 for 1948-49. Appeal for 1949-50 pending before AAC.
Commissioner of Income-tax noticed that the firm could not be registered as one partner was a minor.
Commissioner issued notice under s. 33B(1) to show cause why assessments under s. 23(3) and registration under s. 26A should not be cancelled.
On June 5, 1951, Commissioner passed order under s. 33B(1) cancelling registration under s. 26A and directed ITO to make fresh assessments as unregistered firm for three years.
Income-tax Officer passed fresh orders as a result.
Respondent preferred five appeals to Tribunal: two against AAC orders for 1947-48 and 1948-49 under s. 31; three against CIT orders under s. 33B(1) for three years.
In three appeals, respondent contended: CIT not competent to set aside AAC orders; CIT orders bad as directing ITO in particular manner; subsequent ITO orders bad without notice/hearing.
On January 2, 1952, Tribunal upheld respondent's contentions and allowed appeals.
Appellant moved Tribunal under s. 66(1) for reference; Tribunal referred three questions to Bombay High Court.

Three questions referred: (1) Whether CIT under s.33B(1) can set aside AAC orders for 1947-48,1948-49? (2) Whether CIT order dated 5-6-1951 bad as directing ITO in particular manner? (3) Whether ITO orders dated 21-6-52 bad without fresh notices u/ss.22,23?

Bombay HC on March 5, 1953 held for 1947-48,1948-49: question concluded by CIT Bombay North v. Tejaji Farasram Kharawala; registration merged in appellate order. For 1949-50: CIT cannot revise as appeal pending before AAC. Additional question answered for assessee. CIT order invalid for all years.
HC rejected certificate u/s.66A(2). Appellant obtained special leave from SC on March 22, 1954.

legal_issues.text: Does the order passed by the Income-tax Officer granting registration to the assessee firm continue to be an order passed by the Income-tax Officer even after the assessee’s appeal against the assessment made by the Income-tax Officer on the basis that the assessee was a registered firm has been disposed of by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner? In other words, where the appeal preferred by an assessee against his assessment has been considered and decided by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, does the order of registration along with the subsequent order of assessment merge in the appellate order?

Whether the order of registration in respect of the assessment year 1949-50 can be made the subject-matter of the exercise of the Commissioner’s revisional power even though the assessee’s appeal against the assessment for the said year is pending before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner?

Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the order passed by the Commissioner of Income-tax dated 5th June, 1951, is bad in law as it directs the Income-tax Officer to pass an order in a particular manner?

Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case orders passed by the Income-tax Officer dated 21-6-52 are bad in law, as fresh notices as required by Sections 22 and 23 of the Income-tax Act were not given by the Income-tax Officer to the assessee?

petitioner_arguments.text: The view taken by the High Court that the Commissioner could not exercise revisional power under s.33B in respect of ITO's registration orders for all three years is based on misconstruction of s.33B.
Registration order is independent, separate from assessment order; does not merge in appellate order as it is not appealable by department and AAC has no jurisdiction over it.
Firm cannot be validly registered with minor partner; CIT order correct on merits.
For 1949-50, pendency of appeal does not suspend registration order; no merger yet.
CIT order did not intend to set aside assessments but direct consequential changes post-cancellation; subsequent ITO orders valid without fresh notice as only machinery change.

respondent_arguments.text: Commissioner not competent to set aside assessments confirmed/modified by AAC; registration merges in appellate order.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Principle of merger; CIT Bombay North v. Tejaji Farasram Kharawala

respondent_arguments.text: CIT orders bad as directing ITO to pass order in particular manner.
Subsequent ITO orders bad without notice/hearing u/ss.22,23.
AAC can challenge registration in assessee's appeal against assessment after hearing ITO.

court_reasoning.text: Registration order under s.26A is independent and separate; affects only procedure for collection/recovery under s.23(5)(a)/(b); does not merge in appellate assessment order as not appealable under s.30(1) and AAC lacks jurisdiction over it under s.31.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order granting registration stands outside jurisdiction of AAC; merger theory does not apply.

court_reasoning.text: No appeal by department against registration; AAC powers limited to appealable matters; cannot entertain challenge to registration even with wide s.31 powers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of Act gives assessee appeal right only; department cannot indirectly appeal via AAC.

court_reasoning.text: s.33B applies only to ITO orders erroneous/prejudicial to revenue; registration order revisable by CIT as not appealable elsewhere.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction from s.33A; s.33B excludes appellate orders.

court_reasoning.text: For 1949-50, pendency of appeal does not suspend registration order; CIT can revise as no merger until disposal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Revisional power under s.33B determined by its terms, not policy considerations.

court_reasoning.text: CIT order not setting aside assessments but directing consequential procedure change post-registration cancellation; ITO adopted AAC income figures under s.23(5)(b).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order read as whole shows intent for machinery adjustment.

court_reasoning.text: Question 3 does not arise from proceedings; subsequent ITO procedure consequential, no fresh notice needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only machinery change for unregistered firm.

holdings.text: Registration order does not merge in appellate assessment order; CIT can revise under s.33B(1) even after AAC disposal (for 1947-48, 1948-49).
CIT can revise registration order even if assessment appeal pending before AAC (1949-50).
CIT order dated 5-6-1951 not bad in law.
ITO orders dated 21-6-52 not bad in law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay North v. Tejaji Farasram Kharawala
precedents_cited.relevance: HC relied on merger principle; SC holds inapplicable to registration orders.

precedents_cited.case_name: Durgabati and Narmadabala Gupta v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Patna HC majority followed merger; SC disagrees for registration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Amritlal Bhogilal
Shapurji Pallonji v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Registration affects only machinery, not taxable income computation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rex v. The Special Commissioner of Income-Tax ex parte Elmhirst
precedents_cited.relevance: Appellate authority must arrive at true assessment but limited to appealable matters.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Revisional power under s.33B(1) applicable to ITO registration orders; independent of assessment appeals; directs fresh assessments as unregistered firm.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court reversed Bombay High Court judgment, answered all questions in favor of appellant (CIT): CIT had power under s.33B(1) to cancel registration despite AAC orders or pending appeal; CIT order valid, not directing ITO improperly; subsequent ITO orders valid without fresh notices as only procedural change.
outcome.relief_granted: All questions answered for appellant; HC view reversed.

key_quotes.text: the order granting registration to an assessee firm is an independent and separate order and it merely affects or governs the procedure to be adopted in collecting or recovering the tax found due.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning distinguishing registration from assessment; no merger.

key_quotes.text: the Income-tax Officer’s order granting registration to a firm cannot become the subject-matter of an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits AAC jurisdiction; enables CIT revision.

key_quotes.text: Whether or not the revisional power can be exercised in a given case must be determined solely by reference to the terms of s. 33B itself.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects HC's policy-based limitations on s.33B.
